sn35.15:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I went in search of the eye’s gratification,

sn35.15:1.3.pli: Yāvatā cakkhussa assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn35.15:1.3.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the eye’s gratification.

sn35.15:1.4.eng: I went in search of the eye’s drawback,

sn35.15:1.6.pli: Yāvatā cakkhussa ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn35.15:1.6.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the eye’s drawback.

sn35.15:1.7.eng: I went in search of escape from the eye,

sn35.15:1.9.pli: Yāvatā cakkhussa nissaraṇaṃ, paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.
sn35.15:1.9.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of escape from the eye.

sn35.15:1.10.eng: I went in search of the ear’s …

sn35.15:1.14.pli: Yāvatā jivhāya assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.

sn35.15:1.17.pli: Yāvatā jivhāya ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.

sn35.15:1.20.pli: Yāvatā jivhāya nissaraṇaṃ, paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ …pe…

sn35.15:1.23.pli: Yāvatā manassa assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn35.15:1.23.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the mind’s gratification.

sn35.15:1.24.eng: I went in search of the mind’s drawback,

sn35.15:1.26.pli: Yāvatā manassa ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn35.15:1.26.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the mind’s drawback.

sn35.15:1.27.eng: I went in search of escape from the mind,

sn35.15:1.29.pli: Yāvatā manassa nissaraṇaṃ, paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.
sn35.15:1.29.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of escape from the mind.

sn35.15:2.1.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ channaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ assādañca assādato, ādīnavañca ādīnavato, nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ …pe…
sn35.15:2.1.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening …

sn35.15:2.2.eng: But when I did truly understand …

sn35.15:2.3.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

sn35.15:2.4.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
sn35.15:2.4.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

sn35.150:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.

sn35.150:1.3.pli: katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā?
sn35.150:1.3.eng: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?

sn35.150:1.5.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.150:3.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.150:3.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.150:5.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.150:5.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.150:5.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.150:9.3.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.150:9.3.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.150:11.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.150:11.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.150:13.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.150:13.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.150:13.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.150:15.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati …pe…
sn35.150:15.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact.

sn35.150:15.2.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.150:15.2.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind … painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact.

sn35.150:15.3.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. …

sn35.150:15.4.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’

sn35.150:15.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā”ti.
sn35.150:15.5.eng: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”

sn35.151:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, this spiritual life is lived without a resident pupil and without a teaching master.
sn35.151:1.1.comm: The Vinaya establishes that a newly ordained monastic should live in dependence on a mentor (uppajjhāya) and/or a “tutor” (ācariya) for at least the first five years. If they considered qualified at that point they may be released from dependence. Here the Buddha plays with this idea, inverting the standard meaning.

sn35.151:1.2.pli: Santevāsiko, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sācariyako dukkhaṃ na phāsu viharati.
sn35.151:1.2.eng: A mendicant who lives with a resident pupil and a teaching master lives in suffering and discomfort.

sn35.151:1.3.pli: Anantevāsiko, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anācariyako sukhaṃ phāsu viharati.
sn35.151:1.3.eng: A mendicant who lives without a resident pupil and a teaching master lives in happiness and comfort.

sn35.151:1.4.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhu, santevāsiko sācariyako dukkhaṃ na phāsu viharati?
sn35.151:1.4.eng: And how does a mendicant who lives with a resident pupil and a teaching master live in suffering and discomfort?

sn35.151:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.151:1.5.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.151:1.6.pli: Tyāssa anto vasanti, antassa vasanti pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.
sn35.151:1.6.eng: Those qualities reside within. Since they have bad unskillful qualities residing within,
sn35.151:1.6.comm: The Buddha reveals the pun: the defilements “reside within” (anto vasanti) as a “resident pupil” (antevāsi) lives with the teacher.

sn35.151:1.7.eng: they’re said to have a resident pupil.

sn35.151:1.8.pli: Te naṃ samudācaranti, samudācaranti naṃ pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.
sn35.151:1.8.eng: Those qualities master them. Since they’re mastered by bad unskillful qualities,
sn35.151:1.8.comm: The defilements “master” (samudācaranti) them like a “teaching master” (ācariya).

sn35.151:1.9.eng: they’re said to have a teaching master.

sn35.151:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.151:2.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.151:2.2.pli: Tyāssa anto vasanti, antassa vasanti pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.

sn35.151:2.4.pli: Te naṃ samudācaranti, samudācaranti naṃ pāpakā akusalā dhammāti. Tasmā sācariyakoti vuccati …pe….

sn35.151:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno manasā dhammaṃ viññāya uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.151:3.1.eng: knows an idea with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.151:3.2.pli: Tyāssa anto vasanti, antassa vasanti pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.
sn35.151:3.2.eng: Those qualities reside within. Since they have bad unskillful qualities residing within,

sn35.151:3.3.eng: they’re said to have a resident pupil.

sn35.151:3.4.pli: Te naṃ samudācaranti, samudācaranti naṃ pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.
sn35.151:3.4.eng: Those qualities master them. Since they’re mastered by bad unskillful qualities,

sn35.151:3.5.eng: they’re said to have a teaching master.

sn35.151:3.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santevāsiko sācariyako dukkhaṃ, na phāsu viharati.
sn35.151:3.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant who lives with a resident pupil and a teaching master lives in suffering and discomfort.

sn35.151:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anantevāsiko anācariyako sukhaṃ phāsu viharati?
sn35.151:4.1.eng: And how does a mendicant who lives without a resident pupil and a teaching master live in happiness and comfort?

sn35.151:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.151:4.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.151:4.3.pli: Tyāssa na anto vasanti, nāssa anto vasanti pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.
sn35.151:4.3.eng: Those qualities don’t reside within. Since they don’t have bad unskillful qualities residing within,

sn35.151:4.4.eng: they’re said to not have a resident pupil.

sn35.151:4.5.pli: Te naṃ na samudācaranti, na samudācaranti naṃ pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.
sn35.151:4.5.eng: Those qualities don’t master them. Since they’re not mastered by bad unskillful qualities,

sn35.151:4.6.eng: they’re said to not have a teaching master.

sn35.151:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā na uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.151:5.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.151:5.2.pli: Tyāssa na anto vasanti, nāssa anto vasanti pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.

sn35.151:5.4.pli: Te naṃ na samudācaranti, na samudācaranti naṃ pāpakā akusalā dhammāti. Tasmā anācariyakoti vuccati …pe….

sn35.151:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.151:6.1.eng: knows an idea with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.151:6.2.pli: Tyāssa na anto vasanti, nāssa anto vasanti pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.
sn35.151:6.2.eng: Those qualities don’t reside within. Since they don’t have bad unskillful qualities residing within,

sn35.151:6.3.eng: they’re said to not have a resident pupil.

sn35.151:6.4.pli: Te naṃ na samudācaranti, na samudācaranti naṃ pāpakā akusalā dhammāti.
sn35.151:6.4.eng: Those qualities don’t master them. Since they’re not mastered by bad unskillful qualities,

sn35.151:6.5.eng: they’re said to not have a teaching master.

sn35.151:6.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anantevāsiko anācariyako sukhaṃ phāsu viharati.
sn35.151:6.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant who lives without a resident pupil and a teaching master lives in happiness and comfort.

sn35.151:6.7.eng: This spiritual life is lived without a resident pupil and without a teaching master.

sn35.151:6.8.pli: Anācariyakaṃ santevāsiko, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sācariyako dukkhaṃ, na phāsu viharati.
sn35.151:6.8.eng: A mendicant who lives with a resident pupil and a teaching master lives in suffering and discomfort.

sn35.151:6.9.pli: Anantevāsiko, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anācariyako sukhaṃ phāsu viharatī”ti.
sn35.151:6.9.eng: A mendicant who lives without a resident pupil and a teaching master lives in happiness and comfort.”

sn35.152:0.3.eng: What’s the Purpose of the Spiritual Life?

sn35.152:1.1.pli: “Sace vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn35.152:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:

sn35.152:1.2.eng: ‘Reverends, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’

sn35.152:1.3.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:

sn35.152:1.4.pli: ‘dukkhassa kho, āvuso, pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti.
sn35.152:1.4.eng: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand suffering.’

sn35.152:1.5.pli: Sace pana vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn35.152:1.5.eng: If wanderers of other religions were to ask you:

sn35.152:1.6.pli: ‘katamaṃ panāvuso, dukkhaṃ, yassa pariññāya samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti?

sn35.152:1.7.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:

sn35.152:2.2.eng: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.

sn35.152:2.9.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhaṃ;
sn35.152:2.9.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also suffering.

sn35.152:2.10.eng: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.

sn35.152:2.14.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhaṃ;
sn35.152:2.14.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also suffering.

sn35.152:2.15.eng: The purpose of living the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.

sn35.152:2.17.eng: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.’

sn35.152:2.18.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyāthā”ti.
sn35.152:2.18.eng: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.”

sn35.153:1.1.pli: “Atthi nu kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma bhikkhu aññatreva saddhāya, aññatra ruciyā, aññatra anussavā, aññatra ākāraparivitakkā, aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā aññaṃ byākareyya:
sn35.153:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, is there a method—apart from faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment? That is:

sn35.153:1.2.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmī”ti?
sn35.153:1.2.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’”

sn35.153:1.3.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā, bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
sn35.153:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

sn35.153:1.4.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn35.153:1.4.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn35.153:1.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn35.153:1.7.pli: “atthi, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma bhikkhu aññatreva saddhāya, aññatra ruciyā, aññatra anussavā, aññatra ākāraparivitakkā, aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā aññaṃ byākareyya:
sn35.153:1.7.eng: “There is a method—apart from faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:

sn35.153:1.8.pli: ‘“khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti pajānāmī’ti.
sn35.153:1.8.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’

sn35.153:2.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, pariyāyo, yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma bhikkhu aññatreva saddhāya …pe… aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā aññaṃ byākaroti: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmī’ti?

sn35.153:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, atthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti;
sn35.153:2.2.eng: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. When they have greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand ‘I have greed, hate, and delusion in me.’

sn35.153:2.3.pli: asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, natthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti.
sn35.153:2.3.eng: When they don’t have greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand ‘I don’t have greed, hate, and delusion in me.’

sn35.153:2.4.pli: Yaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, atthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, natthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti. Api nu me, bhikkhave, dhammā saddhāya vā veditabbā, ruciyā vā veditabbā, anussavena vā veditabbā, ākāraparivitakkena vā veditabbā, diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā vā veditabbā”ti?
sn35.153:2.4.eng: Since this is so, are these things understood by faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation?”

sn35.153:2.6.eng: “Aren’t they understood by seeing them with wisdom?”

sn35.153:2.8.pli: “Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma bhikkhu aññatreva saddhāya, aññatra ruciyā, aññatra anussavā, aññatra ākāraparivitakkā, aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā aññaṃ byākaroti:
sn35.153:2.8.eng: “This is a method—apart from faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:

sn35.153:2.9.pli: ‘“khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti pajānāmī’ti …pe….
sn35.153:2.9.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’

sn35.153:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ …pe… rāgadosamohoti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, natthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti.
sn35.153:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant hears a sound … smells an odor … tastes a flavor … feels a touch …

sn35.153:3.2.pli: Yaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, atthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, natthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti; api nu me, bhikkhave, dhammā saddhāya vā veditabbā, ruciyā vā veditabbā, anussavena vā veditabbā, ākāraparivitakkena vā veditabbā, diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā vā veditabbā”ti?

sn35.153:3.6.pli: “Ayampi kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma bhikkhu aññatreva saddhāya, aññatra ruciyā, aññatra anussavā, aññatra ākāraparivitakkā, aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā aññaṃ byākaroti: ‘“khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti pajānāmī’ti …pe….

sn35.153:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu manasā dhammaṃ viññāya santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, atthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti;
sn35.153:4.1.eng: knows an idea with the mind. When they have greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand ‘I have greed, hate, and delusion in me.’

sn35.153:4.2.pli: asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, natthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti.
sn35.153:4.2.eng: When they don’t have greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand ‘I don’t have greed, hate, and delusion in me.’

sn35.153:4.3.pli: Yaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu manasā dhammaṃ viññāya santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, atthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohaṃ, natthi me ajjhattaṃ rāgadosamohoti pajānāti; api nu me, bhikkhave, dhammā saddhāya vā veditabbā, ruciyā vā veditabbā, anussavena vā veditabbā, ākāraparivitakkena vā veditabbā, diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā vā veditabbā”ti?
sn35.153:4.3.eng: Since this is so, are these things understood by faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation?”

sn35.153:4.5.eng: “Aren’t they understood by seeing them with wisdom?”

sn35.153:4.7.pli: “Ayampi kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma bhikkhu aññatreva saddhāya, aññatra ruciyā, aññatra anussavā, aññatra ākāraparivitakkā, aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā aññaṃ byākaroti:
sn35.153:4.7.eng: “This too is a method—apart from faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:

sn35.153:4.8.pli: ‘“khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti pajānāmī’ti.
sn35.153:4.8.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’”

sn35.154:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.154:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn35.154:1.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of someone who is ‘accomplished in the faculties’.
sn35.154:1.2.comm: In SN 48.19, “accomplished in the faculties” is defined as someone who has mastered the five spiritual faculties.

sn35.154:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, indriyasampanno hotī”ti?
sn35.154:1.3.eng: How is someone accomplished in the faculties defined?”

sn35.154:2.1.pli: “Cakkhundriye ce, bhikkhu, udayabbayānupassī viharanto cakkhundriye nibbindati …pe…
sn35.154:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, if someone meditates observing rise and fall in the eye faculty, they grow disillusioned with the eye faculty.

sn35.154:2.2.pli: jivhindriye ce, bhikkhu, udayabbayānupassī viharanto jivhindriye nibbindati …pe…
sn35.154:2.2.eng: If they meditate observing rise and fall in the ear faculty … nose faculty … tongue faculty … body faculty …

sn35.154:2.3.pli: manindriye ce, bhikkhu, udayabbayānupassī viharanto manindriye nibbindati.
sn35.154:2.3.eng: mind faculty, they grow disillusioned with the mind faculty.

sn35.154:2.4.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati …pe… vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.154:2.4.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. … When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.154:2.5.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
sn35.154:2.5.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

sn35.154:2.6.eng: This is how someone who is accomplished in the faculties is defined.”

sn35.155:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.155:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn35.155:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, dhammakathiko hotī”ti?
sn35.155:1.3.eng: How is a Dhamma speaker defined?”

sn35.155:2.1.pli: “Cakkhussa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, ‘dhammakathiko bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn35.155:2.1.eng: “If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.

sn35.155:2.2.pli: Cakkhussa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti, ‘dhammānudhammappaṭipanno bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn35.155:2.2.eng: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.

sn35.155:2.3.pli: Cakkhussa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādāvimutto hoti, ‘diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya …pe…
sn35.155:2.3.eng: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.

sn35.155:2.4.pli: jivhāya ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, ‘dhammakathiko bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya …pe…
sn35.155:2.4.eng: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment with the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.155:2.5.pli: manassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, ‘dhammakathiko bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn35.155:2.5.eng: mind, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.

sn35.155:2.6.pli: Manassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti, ‘dhammānudhammappaṭipanno bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn35.155:2.6.eng: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.

sn35.155:2.7.pli: Manassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādāvimutto hoti, ‘diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
sn35.155:2.7.eng: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”

sn35.156:0.3.eng: The Interior and the End of Relishing

sn35.156:1.1.pli: “Aniccaṃyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhuṃ aniccanti passati, sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
sn35.156:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the eye really is impermanent. A mendicant sees that it is impermanent: that’s their right view.
sn35.156:1.1.comm: This discourse and the next are similar to SN 22.51.

sn35.156:1.3.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.
sn35.156:1.3.comm: “Relishing” (nandi) and “greed” (or “lust”, rāga) are similar in meaning, but with distinct stresses: “relishing” enjoys the object of desire, while “greed” is inflamed by passion for it.

sn35.156:1.5.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is said to be well freed.

sn35.156:1.6.pli: aniccaṃyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jivhaṃ aniccanti passati, sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.

sn35.156:1.11.pli: aniccaṃyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu manaṃ aniccanti passati, sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
sn35.156:1.11.eng: mind really is impermanent. A mendicant sees that it is impermanent: that’s their right view.

sn35.156:1.13.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn35.156:1.15.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is said to be well freed.”

sn35.157:0.3.eng: The Exterior and the End of Relishing

sn35.157:1.1.pli: “Anicceyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpe aniccāti passati, sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
sn35.157:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, sights really are impermanent. A mendicant sees that they are impermanent: that’s their right view.

sn35.157:1.3.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn35.157:1.5.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is said to be well freed.

sn35.157:1.10.pli: dhamme aniccāti passati, sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
sn35.157:1.10.eng: Ideas really are impermanent. A mendicant sees that they are impermanent: that’s their right view.

sn35.157:1.12.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn35.157:1.14.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is said to be well freed.”

sn35.158:0.3.eng: Focus, the Interior, and the End of Relishing

sn35.158:1.1.pli: “Cakkhuṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, cakkhāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.
sn35.158:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, rationally apply the mind to the eye. Truly see the impermanence of the eye.

sn35.158:1.2.pli: Cakkhuṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasikaronto, cakkhāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto cakkhusmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.158:1.2.eng: When a mendicant does this, they grow disillusioned with the eye.

sn35.158:1.3.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn35.158:1.5.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is said to be well freed.

sn35.158:1.6.eng: Rationally apply the mind to the ear …

sn35.158:1.8.pli: jivhaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, jivhāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.

sn35.158:1.9.pli: Jivhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasikaronto, jivhāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto jivhāyapi nibbindati.

sn35.158:1.14.pli: manaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, manāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.
sn35.158:1.14.eng: mind. Truly see the impermanence of the mind.

sn35.158:1.15.pli: Manaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasikaronto, manāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto manasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.158:1.15.eng: When a mendicant does this, they grow disillusioned with the mind.

sn35.158:1.16.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn35.158:1.18.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is said to be well freed.”
